user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish:
```c
void OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(OS_object_token_t *token, const osal_id_t *final_id)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;

    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE)
    {
        /* nothing to do */
        return;
    }

    record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(token);

    /* re-acquire global table lock to adjust refcount */
    if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE || token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT)
    {
        OS_Lock_Global(token);
    }

    if (record->refcount > 0)
    {
        --record->refcount;
    }

    /*
     * at this point the global mutex is always held, either
     * from re-acquiring it above or it is still held from
     * the original lock when using OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL.
     *
     * If an ID update was pending (i.e. for a create/delete op)
     * then do the ID update now while holding the mutex.
     */
    if (final_id != NULL)
    {
        record->active_id = *final_id;
    }
    else if (token->lock_mode == OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE)
    {
        /*
         * If the lock type was EXCLUSIVE, it means that the ID in the record
         * was reset to OS_OBJECT_ID_RESERVED.  This must restore the original
         * object ID from the token.
         */
        record->active_id = token->obj_id;
    }

    /* always unlock (this also covers OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL case) */
    OS_Unlock_Global(token);

    /*
     * Setting to "NONE" indicates that this token has been
     * released, and should not be released again.
     */
    token->lock_mode = OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining parts of the function are simple declarations, comments, or single obvious statements that do not by themselves indicate unreachable code and therefore do not require investigation: - The declaration of 'OS_common_record_t *record;' is non-executable and cannot be unreachable. - The assignment 'record = OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(token);' is a direct call used later and is reachable from all non-returning paths. - The comment blocks are non-executable and not relevant to reachability. - There is no other code following the final assignment to token->lock_mode that could be statically unreachable. The listed fragments are those containing conditional logic or control-flow-affecting calls (early return, conditional locking/unlocking, conditional assignment and refcount modification) that could hide unreachable branches or mismatched lock/unlock pairs and therefore should be investigated for possible unreachable code or incorrect control flow.
